name: Lizard King Canyon
description:
Introduction

Thanks to Scott Swaney for pioneering this canyon. Lizard King is a canyon in the Grapevine Mountains of Death Valley. It is a good half day canyon with an easy approach, 7 rappels and some cool blue narrows in its lower reaches - perfect for those people looking for a fun, non-epic, non-marathon Death Valley canyoneering experience. It does have some minor anchor challenges such as a webbing knot choke anchor in a crack - so moderate anchor building skills are required.

Approach

From the intersection of Scotty's Castle Road and CA-190 W it is about 12 miles north on Scotty's Castle road to the parking area. Park a few hundred feet north of the road side marker/alluvial fan info sign. You have your choice of either a left or right side approach to the top of Lizard King. The easier of the two is up the Alluvial Fan to the right. From the top of the fan just below the dry fall take a left up to the ridge of a hidden couloir. Follow this ridge north then north east over to the upper south drainage of Lizard King. Follow this drainage down to the intersection with the north drainage. From here it is short distance down canyon to the first rappel.

Descent

The canyon has 7 rappels.

R1: From a knot choked piece of webbing- 50 feet.

R2: From a rock cairn, two stage, 45 feet, 65 feet - 110 total - we used about 120 feet of rope

R3: From a piece of webbing lodged in a pinch point - 35 feet.

R4: From a Rock Cairn, two stage, 30 feet, 65 feet - 95 total.

R5: From a piece of webbing lodged in a pinch point - 30 feet.

R6: From a Rock Cairn - 25 feet

R7: From Webbing around a large boulder - 50 feet. Clumsy start on this one. Down climb on the right past the anchor, RDC for easier start.

Exit

Red tape

Beta sites

Background

Originally explored by Scott Swaney on 2011-02-05 under the identifier "G 26.". See more at Scott Swaney's Death Valley Canyoneering Exploration.
